title: HTML Document Structure
subject: HTML
theory:
# The HTML Boilerplate

Every standardized HTML document follows a specific structure, often called the "boilerplate". This ensures that browsers read and display the page correctly.

## The `<!DOCTYPE html>` Declaration

The `<!DOCTYPE html>` declaration must be the **very first thing** in your HTML document, before the `<html>` tag. It is not an HTML tag; it is an instruction to the web browser about what version of HTML the page is written in.
*   In HTML5, it is simply: `<!DOCTYPE html>`
*   It is case-insensitive.

## The `<html>` Element

The `<html>` element is the **root element** of an HTML page. All other elements must be descendants of this element.
*   We often add the `lang` attribute to declare the language of the page: `<html lang="en">`.

## The `<head>` Element

The `<head>` element contains **meta-information** about the HTML page. This information is **not visible** to the page visitor (except for the page title in the browser tab).
It typically includes:
*   `<title>`: The title shown in the browser tab.
*   `<meta charset="UTF-8">`: Defines the character encoding (to support all characters).
*   Links to CSS files.
*   Links to JavaScript files.

## The `<body>` Element

The `<body>` element defines the **document's body**. It contains all the **visible contents**, such as headings, paragraphs, images, hyperlinks, tables, lists, etc.

There can be only **one** `<body>` element in an HTML document.

common_mistakes.correction: Always include the doctype so browsers render in Standards Mode instead of Quirks Mode.
Visible content like headings and text must go in <body>.
An HTML document can have only one body element.

interview_questions.question: What is the purpose of the <!DOCTYPE> declaration?
interview_questions.answer: It informs the browser about the version of HTML used in the document, ensuring it renders in Standards Mode rather than Quirks Mode.

interview_questions.question: What is the difference between <head> and <body>?
interview_questions.answer: <head> contains metadata (title, scripts, styles) not visible on the page, while <body> contains the visible content rendered by the browser.

interview_questions.question: Why do we use the lang attribute in the <html> tag?
interview_questions.answer: It specifies the language of the document (e.g., lang='en'), which helps search engines and screen readers for accessibility.

practice_problems.problem: Write a complete HTML5 boilerplate code structure.
practice_problems.hint: Start with doctype, then html, head, title, body.

real_world_use_cases.description: Without the correct structure and DOCTYPE, browsers may switch to 'Quirks Mode' to emulate older bugs, potentially breaking your layout.

exam_notes: Structure is strictly nested: html > (head + body)
summary: The HTML document structure is the foundation of every web page. It begins with the <!DOCTYPE html> declaration, followed by the <html> root element, which contains two main sections: <head> for metadata and <body> for visible content. Mastering this boilerplate is essential for writing valid HTML.
